Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: A fellow activist is live-streaming from a small demonstration right now and has asked for more people to show up if they are free.
Story: I stare at my phone, the screen lighting up with two messages. One is from my boyfriend, asking if we can talk tonight—he says we need to sort things out, that we can’t keep fighting about money. The other is from Maya, a fellow activist, her text urgent: “We need more people at the protest. Can you come now?” I feel my chest tighten. I know how important it is to be there, to show up for the cause I care about, especially when so few are willing to stand in public. But I also know that if I don’t try to fix things with him, the distance between us will only grow. He expects me to be present, to listen, to help us find a way through our arguments. My friends expect me to be reliable, to put the movement first. I pace the room, torn between the person I love and the cause I believe in, wishing I could be in two places at once.
